ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about psych experiments and techniques as well as foundations of human learning and memory
I have learned the basic methods of how people learn and remember, starting with psychology/research methods as well as some neuroscience techniques.

I have learned a lot about the psychology behind learning and memory. I have learned a little about the neuroscience behind learning and memory. So think about this as a cognitive psychology class. For comparison, I learned more about the neuroscience of learning and memory in PSYC 160 than in this course, which is fine, but if you are looking for the neuroscience behind learning and memory, this course won't give you much.
Understanding the systems of different forms of learning and memory through a psychological lens.
I gained an immense and deeper understanding of the psychological and neural processes that undelrie learning and memory.
I learned so much in this course! I learned how memory and learning work in the brain.
A very interesting class about learning and memory
Understanding of the human memory and learning system
Good course on the mechanisms and psychology begind learning.  A lot of material going deeper into typical areas feom psychology, with some neuroscience extras added in
Basic knowledge on learning and memory
I learned the basics of learning and memory in the brain
I learned about the processes of learning and memory, both behaviorally and from a neurological perspective.
I learned about learning and memory from an interdisciplinary perspective that connected philosophy and neuroscience.
understanding of both learning and memory, contemporary neuroscience's take on it as well as some practical applications
I learned so much about how the brain learns skills and processes information different types of memory, and how the brain develops.
I learned the basic neuroscience behind learning and memory in the human brain.

As we learned about learning and memory in the brain, the skills were transferrable to real life and how to best study. 
This was one of the best interdisciplinary courses I took and I saw it apply to other course areas and activities I was doing.
Learned a lot about myself through this class.
I learned a little bit about the content

This is a great survey course in different kinds of learning and memory. There was some intro psych stuff at the beginning and we learned about how people learn and retain information for school and in other concepts, working memory, and conditioning.

I learned a general overview of learning and memory -- I especially enjoyed the second half of the course! Some of the course was definitely review if you are a CogSci or Psych major but I still came away with new knowledge. It was an interesting topic and it changed the way I think about some day-to-day aspects of learning and memory.
Lot of studies and experiments that were very interesting and not a focus of other psychology classes offered so it was nice to get exposed in this class
Great Course! I really felt like I gained an overall understanding of memory but we never did dive much into any topic.

I learned about various subtypes of memory, including but not limited to declarative (i.e. semantic and episodic) memory and working memory, as well as various subtypes of learning, such as classical conditioning, operant conditioning, reinforcement learning, social learning, and emotional learning.
I learned about the how learning and memory is encoded within the brain, the structures that are involved, and the various ways in which learning and memory can be affected.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths were the curriculum content and lectures
More neurobiology/biology and slightly less pure psychology
no feedback on our writing responses :(

Strengths: Not a lot of homework assignments, workload is very manageable, Sam is very responsive with emails 

Weaknesses: For a big psych/neuro lecture course, this class was not recorded and that made it a little difficult to catch up with lectures. Sometimes lecture slides were a bit confusing so I would often go to office hours as well.
Interesting content, not very engaging. Perhaps more technical homework assignments.

Strengths - very engaging lectures, exams are very solidly based on the course material
Weaknesses - the 4 homeworks are each on an individual paper so there wasn't much integration of knowledge before the tests
I found the content that defined this course incredibly interesting and I looked forward to each and every class!
Well structured lectures but you should keep up with lectures
The course couldve been a bit more organized and engaging but The material was good

Strengths were that it was interesting info and format of the class was pretty good. Weaknesses are with the way info was presented - lectures werent recorded making it hard to review and professor talked too fast
Lecture slides are easy to follow, but class was not recorded, so it was difficult not being able to go back and listen

The course is poorly structured. We had two tests, both of which were non-cumulative and worth 25% of our grade, but one covered 5-6 lectures while the second covered 12. The lectures are also not recorded, and the slides are have minimal context, so if you are sick or contact-traced, you have to find time to attend office hours or carefully read the textbook to get caught up.

The pacing and lecture style in this course was overall pretty good: I felt like I could process the material but we also moved through material quickly. This course could be improved by adding more student participation, possibly through sections.

Strengths: course content easy to follow.

Weaknesses: sort of hard to engage, and course notes were never published/course recordings/livestreams so if you missed due to illness it was impossible to catch up. I think the professor should offer livestream/class recordings.
great course!
This course is awesome. I think the course is structured very well to maximize student learning.
I have no critiques on the course.

I appreciated that the slides were posted, but sometimes they were lacking some descriptors; the presenter comments would have been helpful.
Homework was a perfect balance of easy to complete but also forced me to synthesize what I had learned in class.

If we had a non-cumulative final, it should have been during the last week of classes and not Finals period!!
Slides could be more informative

strengths: covered a wide variety of topics
weaknesses: prof wasn't enthusiastic about technical content which made us less enthusiastic. course covers way too much intro psych content vs the content that I actually wanted to learn

how it could be improved: reduce lecture to 50 min (we would end early most days anyway) and add a section

Strengths: this class was well organized and the professor was very available to help via email or zoom or even in person after class. The course was interesting and accessible to people who don't have a strong background in psych but were interested in the topic. I felt that the assignments were fair and expectations were clear. I love that this course didn't have a section. 

Weaknesses: I think the class reading was very backloaded and it got a little overwhelming towards the end. The class is graded on participation, but the forms of participation available to use in a lecture outside of attendance can be a little intimidating for those who don't have a strong psych background because of the difference in prior knowledge in the class. I hope that office hours and etc can count towards participation as well, especially for those who might be more reticent to speak up in class.

I think Sam was a great lecturer and a professor who was very considerate of the needs of his students during this time. I really appreciated his flexibility and willingness to make accessibility adjustments to the course as needed.
The professor is very organized and the content is explained clearly. Be warned, the first quiz is more of an exam. It caught a lot of people off guard.
The lectures were slightly difficult to understand--sometimes the concepts were talked about in such specific detail that it was hard to grasp the broad scope of things.
I really enjoyed it!

Strengths: Topics were interesting, there was not too much work, and the work was always enjoyable, feeling like I had truly taken away something from the course

Weakness: can feel slightly like just a number in the course

The pace of this course was very practical for student learning. However, there seemed to be a moderate amount of overlap with AP Psychology, and I wish that this course would have focused more on the neurobiology of various memory subtypes.

The course is very intuitive, everything that was on the lecture slides or reading was seen on the test at some point and there were no trick questions, all the content was pretty straightforward. If you have taken a basic psychology course before, then the course content would be pretty familiar. There is only lecture without section, and the way information was organized and delivered on the slides in class were concise and easy to understand.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes but only for a high-level pretty non-technical understanding of learning and memory
Yes! I think for the psychology natural science core it was definitely a manageable and introductory level to a learning and memory psychology course.
I would, I learned interesting things in a relatively chill and low-stress environment.
Yes! It is a great class with a lot of information but also very chill and not a large workload.
I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone who is even remotely interested in Neuroscience and the cognitive processes that underlie learning and memory.
Yes! Very engaging and fun
Definitely yes. Very interesting (more psychology focuses than neuroscience focused)
yes i thought it was interesting
Yes!! Take this class if you get the chance.
Yes i would, its overall a good interesting course. Exam difficulty is a bit lop sided so maybe go to office hours to get clarification.
Yes, take this course. The subject matter was interesting, and approachable as someone with an elementary understanding of psych and neuroscience. It's a nice 5th class for your schedule.

I highly recommend this course! Prof. McDougle is a very engaging professor and his lectures are always interesting and filled with great real-life examples to tie to the lecture content. The lectures reference related studies in psychology and neuroscience which really aids learning and the varying examples of research studies help improve your understanding. The class has 1 quiz and 2 tests/exams, spaced throughout the semester, so the courseload doesn't feel too heavy at all. I personally think this class is one where you can enjoy every part of the learning process, from lectures to readings, and I recommend this class to anyone with an interest in memory!
Yes very accessible to non neuro person
Yes, I would recommend this to anyone interested in neuroscience and who has time to devote to properly processing all of the information taught in the course.
No, I think there was not enough homework/class material to feel engaged, but the tests were oddly extremely harshly graded and difficult to do well on.
yes! great and fun science credit, but will have to commit to studying for 3 exams.
yes, it is one of my favorite courses at Yale! I believe any student would find this interesting no matter what major they are pursuing.
I truly would. Professor McDougle does a great job covering the basics of learning and memory for a psychology or neuroscience major.
Yes, it was a great intro course to "Brain" (Cog sci, psych, neuroscience) without being either too technical or too theoretical.
not really. Even if you thought the content was interesting, the course was hard to follow and it was basically intro psych.
Yes! I learned a lot, and the course was really fair.
Yes! It's interesting and you learn a lot about learning. It's also potentially an interesting and different perspective for those into education studies!

A good lecture to fulfill a credit for Cog Sci or Psych! Some of the class was definitely review on what I have learned in past courses, but I came away with some interesting new knowledge about learning and memory! Sam is great and I really appreciated that it wasn't an overly stressful course while still facilitating learning.
Yes!
Yes!
Yes! Super interesting and really engaging Professor and TAs

yes if you need a behavior core for the neuroscience major, it isn't the most amount of work, the professor is very reasonable in what he expects you to memorize for the exams, not everything that is said in lecture has to be regurgitated in the exams,
Absolutely! It was interesting, well taught, and had applicable material.
Yes. This course sufficiently covers the basics of learning and memory, as well as many classic, foundational experiments and case studies (i.e. Patient H.M.).

Yes, I would recommend this as a 5th course. It is a pretty relaxed time with few assignments and most of the grades relying on the exams. The exams are pretty easy if you pay attention in class and study a few days before the exam, so it should be pretty easy to do well in the class. The professor is funny and the content is pretty enjoyable, so I would recommend this class to others.
Yes
